docs.lead_paragraph: At this year's Academy Awards extravaganza (rooted in the Latin extravagantem, ''to wander beyond,'' with an Italian ending that lifts it into ''spectacular entertainment''), a nominee in 11 categories is Martin Scorsese's ''The Aviator,'' about the eccentric aviation innovator and pioneering movie producer Howard Hughes. (If you're rich, you're ''eccentric''; if you're poor, you're nuts.) One scene in that film is fixed in my memory because it may feature an anachronism. The classic example of such a time warp of phraseology is in Shakespeare's ''Julius Caesar,'' set in ancient times, in which Cassius says, ''The clock hath stricken three.'' The Bard forgot that clocks that strike the hour had probably not been invented at the time. In ''The Aviator,'' a glittering party is held to celebrate the conclusion of the filming of Hughes's 1930 epic, ''Hell's Angels.'' What struck me was a large sign with red lettering: ''Hell's Angels 'It's a Wrap.' '' The placement of the phrase within quotation marks suggests it was fresh at the time. But was it? Or did the director or screenwriter project a current phrase back in time?
docs.abstract: On Language column by William Safire explores meaning and derivation of phrases 'that's a wrap' and 'the game is not worth the candle' (M)

docs.snippet: The marketing of the Oscars proves that it is still the American way to lament indecency even while gobbling it up....
docs.lead_paragraph: THE total box office for all five best-picture nominees on tonight's Oscars is so small that their collective niche in the national cultural marketplace falls somewhere between square dancing and non-Grisham fiction. But if this year's Oscars are worthless as a barometer of the broad state of American pop culture, there's much to learn from the hype spun by ABC and the motion picture academy to seduce Americans to watch even if they can't distinguish Clive Owen from Catalina Sandino Moreno. The selling of the Oscar show is the latest indicator of the most telling disconnect in our politics: in the post-Janet Jackson era, ''indecency'' is gaining in popularity in direct proportion to Washington's campaign to shut indecency down. Hollywood can read the numbers. Once the feds vowed to smite future ''wardrobe malfunctions,'' the customers started bolting the annual TV franchises where those malfunctions and their verbal counterparts are apt to occur. An award show sanitized of vulgarity and encased in the prophylactic of tape delay is an oxymoron. And so the Golden Globes lost 40 percent of its audience in January on NBC, the Grammys lost 28 percent of its audience this month on CBS. The viewers turned up instead at the competing ''Desperate Housewives'' on ABC, where S-and-M is the latest item on the carnal menu. Though this year's Super Bowl didn't have to go up against that runaway hit, its born-again family-friendliness also took a ratings toll; the audience in the all-important 18-to-49 demographic fell to an all-time low. The viewers perked up only for a GoDaddy.com commercial parodying a Washington ''Broadcast Censorship Hearing'': TiVo reported that the spot's utterly unrevealing ''wardrobe malfunction'' gag was the most replayed moment from any of the game's ads, much as the Jackson-Timberlake pas de deux that inspired it was the TiVo sensation of the year before.
docs.abstract: Frank Rich column on ABC and motion picture academy's effort to lure TV viewers back to annual Oscars show by implying that comedian Chris Rock, who is this year's host, will bring 'indecency' to the program; photo; drawing (M)

docs.snippet: Professional stunt performers deserve their own Oscar category....
docs.lead_paragraph: WE stunt performers have come a long way from the days of falling into cardboard boxes or through boards laid over sawhorses. It has been a long time since anyone has done a ''saddle drag'' with just a rope down his pant leg tied to the stirrup of a runaway horse. If you were knocked unconscious, you would naturally let go of the rope and eventually bounce to a stop. A lot has changed since those days of wild and woolly stunts. But even though much of today's action is enabled by specialized equipment and technology, the reaction to our work is the same: audiences are always thrilled by stunts. Why isn't the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences? By recognizing stunt performers with their own Oscar category, the academy could show that it, too, values the skill and daring that go into making some of Hollywood's most popular movies.

docs.snippet: During the Oscars, Robin Williams had planned to mock the tempest over SpongeBob SquarePants, then he faced critics of his own....
docs.lead_paragraph: ABC executives have forced Robin Williams to drop a comic song from the Oscars show that might well have proved one of the most political and racy numbers of the broadcast, despite the fact that the network and the show's host, Chris Rock, have been promoting the night as anything but tame. Mr. Williams, the presenter of the Academy Award for best animated feature, decided last week that his one minute on stage would be a prime time to lampoon the conservative critic James C. Dobson, whose group Focus on the Family last month criticized the cartoon character SpongeBob SquarePants for appearing in a video about tolerance that the group called ''pro-homosexual.''

docs.snippet: Watching films unfold in my retirement....
docs.lead_paragraph: THE Academy Awards presentation tonight represents a special time for me. The Oscars this year coincide almost exactly with the anniversary of my retirement; and in the interim I've been making up for all the years that I couldn't go to movies without being jammed into a crowded theater in bad seats. Before our liberation, my wife had a day job and I worked evenings. Practically speaking that left us with weekend afternoons and nights, when theaters were most crowded, to go to the movies.

docs.snippet: The star of "The Sea Inside" goes outside, slouching and shopping along the Sunset Strip....
docs.lead_paragraph: BY ordinary standards, Javier Bardem, with his broken nose and his I-could-be-a-bricklayer outfit (hoodie, jeans, work boots and an antiwar T-shirt bearing an obscene slogan), might not be considered a hunk. But one of the earmarks of a true hunk is that he not appear to know he is a hunk; by that measure, Mr. Bardem is the real deal. Hunk or not, he can act. Mr. Bardem became the first Spaniard nominated for an Oscar for best actor, for his role as a homosexual Cuban poet imprisoned by Fidel Castro in ''Before Night Falls.'' In his current film, ''The Sea Inside,'' Mr. Bardem, who is 36, portrays a 55-year-old quadriplegic fighting the Spanish government for the right to die. With only facial expressions to convey emotion, Mr. Bardem won a nomination for a Golden Globe as best actor in a drama. ''The Sea Inside'' took the Golden Globe for best foreign film and is a nominee for an Oscar in the same category.

docs.snippet: Tonight Americans will be tuning in, as we always do this time of year, for another episode of television's oldest reality program, the Academy Awards....
docs.lead_paragraph: Tonight Americans will be tuning in, as we always do this time of year, for another episode of television's oldest reality program, the Academy Awards. Like ''Survivor'' or ''Fear Factor'' or ''The Apprentice,'' it shows us a version of the world in which the audience is invited to watch real people react spontaneously to unexpected events -- and it just so happens that in this world, almost the entire population is wrinkle- and cellulite-free. It would be nice to pretend that most of us watch the Academy Awards to see who wins the big Oscars late in the evening. But the real fun is seeing the most famous people on the planet doing things that we ourselves have done, like walking, sitting and clapping. Year after year, the best part of the show is always the audience reaction shots -- Will Smith here, Angelina Jolie there, Jack Nicholson grinning front and center. This is the nearest many of us will ever get to seeing a movie star almost unaware of being observed.
docs.abstract: Editorial notes that Americans will be tuning in on Feb 27 for another episode of television's oldest reality program, the Academy Awards; says the program is holding its own when it comes to the size of its television audience, but other awards shows appear to be losing their audience shares; holds that awards shows may be suffering from the success of reality TV
